Mgmt openly admits you have too much work on your plate but doesn’t do anything to improve processes or appropriately manage their expectations. You get ample PTO but there is no backup person keeping up on the claims when you take PTO, so taking any time off puts you significantly behind even if you just take one or two day’s off, & then you’re either expected to work a ton of overtime before or after you take PTO to catch up. So there’s ample PTO but using it only makes work harder to keep up with. Instead of expecting your employees to run themselves ragged on a regular basis trying to manage a workload that’s meant for two people, you need to manage your expectations appropriately. You admit openly that the workload is astronomical but instead of hiring on more ppl to evenly distribute claims, you pile it on your existing employees & you keep saying we have to be under 20 tasks per week whether we have 70 claims or 170 claims. That’s unreasonable. There’s only so many hours in the day & we get tired of working 6 days a week every week to meet unreasonable demands. pros:
Large Company with benefits and potential for career growth.
With some jobs expect the generous chance to work from home multiple days a week.
cons:
Not all departments are run equally and career growth is dependent on your leadership. After 9+ years I would see careers including my own prosper if the person was luck to have a good leader. If unlucky to have bad or incompetent leader, then even the best employee was passed over for promotions and had to prepare for daily frustration in their job.
 
Even for good employees, if you work there a long time then expect the pay increase from promotions to not match the external market.
Advice to Management
My experience was with Express Scripts for +9 years. I was able to experience multiple mergers and acquiring other companies. In that time I was promoted or took on a new role about every 2-3 years. This allowed me to see different departments and managers. From that experience I can say not all areas of the business are treated the same. 

 I decided to leave in 2019 after they were acquired by Cigna (I only worked under Cigna for about 6 months, and did not see major changes during that time). The major reason for leaving was due to pay.

With my multiple promotions, I learned the company was willing to pay a new hire off the street more than someone that had just promoted internally. HR will say each role has a range based on experience, education, etc. 
 But they also consider the percentage increase when the new role is an internal promotion. 

Because of this decision, the company could have two employees with the same job but the internal candidate is pay less than the new hire. Often the internal employee was faster at acclamation to the new role. They did not need time to learning the company culture or obtain access to programs and systems. But for the pay system, that did not matter as the decision was made during the hiring/promotion phase and not 3-6 months after the person was in the role. 

My direct leadership understood this was a problem, but could only make up for it during annual reviews. On paper I was a stretch employee, but due to additional red tape the leadership was limited by HR on the max percentage an employee's pay could increased each year. I am sure some would argue that better leadership would have found a way, but that gets back to each department is not equal from my experience.

I calculated the difference in my case and found it would take 3-4 additional years with the maxed percentage before I would be even with my peers. That would not make up the time and interest lost, and it did not take into consideration the potential to be promoted and restart the clock.

The fact that my leaders knew this was a problem but HR was unwilling to adjust their policy lead me to look outside the company. I liked what I was doing, and the people I worked with. In this case, I learned getting a year outside and coming back into the company would be a better financial move personally than trying to be promoted internally.
